qas.question: What does DST inherit from standard time?
Does daylight savings sometimes minimize or magnify the drawbacks of standard time?
Usually, it's recommended that we avoid the sun for how many hours before and after noon?
What kind of guidelines become less precise because of DST?
When using a sundial, we must adjust the reading to reflect natural discrepancies and the effect of what other influence?

context: DST inherits and can <a1_0>magnify<a1_0/> the <a0_0>disadvantages<a0_0/> of standard time. For example, when reading a sundial, one must compensate for it along with <a4_0>time zone<a4_0/> and natural discrepancies. Also, <a3_0>sun-exposure guidelines<a3_0/> such as avoiding the sun within <a2_0>two<a2_0/> hours of noon become less accurate when DST is in effect.
